history.content: Hey! Let me know if you ever want to do homework together! I'm also down to grab boba or coffee sometime. Even though it may all seem hard right now, I am confident that you will come out of this ok. At the end of the day, we are able to withstand a lot more than we think we can. :)

children.subject: Not OP, but this is a great answer. Thanks for the insights!

Re: not being good at CS - you're a CS/EECS major at Berkeley so that probably isn't true. Regardless of how you're doing in classes, you know more about CS than the vast majority of people out there and will probably be fine in the long run.

I'd also suggest keeping an open mind about career paths, since you never know where life will take you. Maybe you'll want to work a tech job in a non-tech industry, or maybe you'll find that you're into something else entirely. There's a good chance you won't have to be a super hardcore CS person to do the job really well. Hell, my plans for what classes I'm gonna take and when has changed a zillion times since I started college (and I'm a sophomore), how am I supposed to know what I'll be doing 5-10 years after graduation? Lol

Re: friendships - I feel you on this one. I came from a really small high school where people knew each other very, very well - almost too well. If you made a bad impression when you started school you were pretty much screwed for the next 4 years (I guess that's true to some degree for all high schools but wtv). I had a very close circle of friends who I pretty much spent all my time with, and I'm still in contact with them to this day. But it felt limiting, and that's why I chose to move across the country to Berkeley, even as the only person from my high school class to come here.

I was very overconfident in my ability to make new friends and didn't take into account how different college friendships - and high school friendships - are from high school, especially at a huge public school like Berkeley. I had my fair share of terrible experiences my first year trying to meet people and adjusting to Berkeley's individualistic culture.

By "individualistic culture", I mean that we're all super ambitious and have our own goals, which makes opportunities for sharing time with people harder to come by. Friendships these days tend to have a more specific focus - I have my CS friends where we pretty much only ever talk about CS stuff, I'm friends with my roommates where we just kinda talk about the things that happen to us throughout the day, etc. Other people bond pretty strongly over clubs. The people using you for homework help? They might actually be trying to connect, and that's the easiest way they feel they can do that when that's the only connection you share with them. 

What I've learned about friendships the last two years -

1. Friendships now require time, and most importantly effort. In high school you're forced to spend time with the same people a lot, which means friendships could form even when you don't try to make them happen. This isn't true at all in college, especially in a department as big as CS/EECS, or in real life - you need to put in the work to make new friendships, and even to maintain the ones you already have. Which ties nicely into my next point:

2. Keep putting yourself out there. I struggle with this all the time - yeah it's scary, but it's one of those things you have to do. You will fall flat on your face time and time again - I certainly did. Maybe people won't be responsive, or you don't vibe with them, whatever. There are times when it will suck. But you're still closer to finding real connections if you're putting yourself out there than if you're not, even if it takes you years to find them. You miss 100% of the shots you don't take. And the shots you do take? I guarantee you you'll find a hit eventually :)

Keep your head up! Life gets better.

Yes, I'm feeling the same way as well. One of my friend could literally finish 20 minutes of code in cs61 while I spent several hours on it. Some of cs majors seem to be so smart and genius that even if we study hard for years we could not compete with them. I feel entirely overwhelmed. Even if I study with them, they often say themselves that "I am a idiot" or something like that. That is the most frustrated moment.

Hey anons above, I came into 61A having never coded in my life and ended up with a really bad grade while everyone around me seemed like they were getting A's. But I worked my ass off in 61B with Hug, learned a tremendous amount, and did a lot better than I did in 61A. 

Those coding geniuses might've coded for hundreds of hours in high school; the point is, you don't know other people's backgrounds and experiences so there's no use in comparing yourself them. You only know your background and your experience, so focus on personal growth. 

Lastly, life's a marathon. So what those coding geniuses can figure out a question in 20 minutes right now? Just know that hard work and passion will bring you places nothing else can. :)

I literally feel the same way!! I constantly feel so stupid and I absolutely suck at coding :), and no one wants to hang out with me beside a few people who need help on cs70. My group of friends are closer to each other than they are to me, and it just seems like I am not important enough to anyone. 

Besides this, I can't even get good grades in most of my classes. Sometimes I wonder if I should just quit CS since I apparently am too dumb. I do have passion, but that alone is not enough.

But then I think about how i am also not good at anything else beside cs. I feel like i can't even switch majors. Also I'm an international student, so if I don't get a job after graduation I'll be kicked out of this country. I am constantly scared and worried about my future. 

Sorry for the ranting, but please know that you are not alone ;) lmk if u wanna talk or do hw together at anytime. Also to fellow students, if this post annoys you, please just ignore it and do not post hateful replies. I'm very broken right now :)

As other repliers have pointed out above, you are not alone!! I've definitely felt this way... Everyone experiences feeling alone, inadequate, broken, lost. It's okay to be struggling with these feelings and I'm grateful to you for sharing this on here because others can see this post and relate to it and we can come together and be more supportive and compassionate towards each other.

Something that helps me is to stop, really stop, and look at what I'm grateful for and what's good. It really works. When I make that my focus, it's really inspiring. You can focus on the happiness of being here learning at Berkeley, the happiness of drinking some water, the happiness of just exchanging one smile or laugh with someone, anything big or small, don't let it slip away, really let yourself experience that joy.

As another replier said, you are at Berkeley so you are definitely smart, strong, capable, and highly employable. I also think it's true what the other replier said about how people who might seem like they just want homework help might also be trying to connect. My personal experience has been that true friendships have come into my life when I least expected it, even when I was not looking for it, but when I was just focusing on the positive in life and trying to become a stronger and kinder person then I ended up in places where I met people who were doing the same and we connected in that.

Don't be so hard on yourself. Believe in yourself. You will be ok. <3

Hope you plan to join some clubs on campus bc that’s a great way to make friends. GREAT way to make friends. But clubs are so hard to join in Berkeley because there’s so much demand. So also consider maybe starting a new club and see where it goes :)

history.content:
I've been feeling really bad today. Feel like I have no genuine friends, just people who use me for homework help. Not confident i'll have friends when i'm older. Not confident I will stay employed after graduation because i'm not really good at CS.

Just feel shitty today. What to do?
history.subject: Feeling Alone With No Hope For Future?
